Rather than animating with an ObjectAnimator, why not just do ```view.animate().scaleX(scalex).scaleY(scaley).setDuration(duration).start();``` ?

according to <http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28220613/what-is-the-difference-between-an-animator-and-an-animation>
Animation is an older version animators.

attachments.title: What is the difference between an Animator and an Animation?
attachments.text: It looks like both Animations and Animators allow me to animate properties (position, opacity, scale, rotation, etc) on objects, and I'm having a hard time differentiating between the use case for ...
attachments.fallback: What is the difference between an Animator and an Animation?

text: <@U3C0PTBB2> have you considered using this library which seems to be doing exactly what you are doing underneath except has probably figured out these quirks? <https://github.com/blipinsk/ViewPropertyObjectAnimator>

attachments.title: blipinsk/ViewPropertyObjectAnimator
attachments.text: ViewPropertyObjectAnimator - Wrapper of the ObjectAnimator that can be used similarly to ViewPropertyAnimator

text:
```return ViewPropertyObjectAnimator
        .animate(view)
        .scaleX(scaleX)
        .scaleY(scaleY)
        .setDuration(duration)
        .get();
```
it worked when i used it, you should check it out
looks good. Going to give it a try. Thanks for the tip

jesus christ
remeber my splash screen?
since it is the main entry pont I placed a logic there that if an account already exist in the account manager, there is token and is valid
then that user is logged therefore proceed to Dashboard
When dashboard logsout, it goes to SplashScreen triggering that logic returning me back to Dashboard
Technically we don't have invalidate token per se
I did the best practice I could and put it in Account Manager where that token is safe
I don't even store password on the device. They suggested otherwise, they suggested to put it on the local file space (e.g. shared preference) which I know is not the right way
So my only way of logging out is to just send the user back to splashscreen to login again (loggin in gives the user new token)
heck we don't event have an api for invalidating token
I think they have dumb it down a bit for the project

hello I am trying to figure out how to detect memory leaks in my app, and have found leakcanary... however, I can't figure out how to make sense of their report...
<@U37BP6E73|arviio> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/arviio/F3CR88TAR/screenshot_from_2016_12_09_19_01_00.png|Screenshot from 2016 12 09 19 01 00.png>
I'm not the best expert in leak canary but what I think is that you need to look at your code in those places leak canary highlighted for you
<@U3CNTME9G|zontag> has joined the channel
Then you need to understand/think about android concepts and if you need/should change anything in your code or if that memory leak actually makes your app crash or makes something mal functioning

Example: if you have an instance and somehow that instance is leaked (GC in action making it null), but if the next time you use that instance you re-initialize it, then leak canary would tell you: "you have a leak here" but you did recover sucessfully for that leak
At least that's how I see it / use it. But feel free to correct my assumptions if they are wrong :slightly_smiling_face:
I don't get how I LeakCanary says I don't have any leaks
I faked one and that was showing up, I just don't get how my code did not get a single leak

text: thanks <@U39P7U6EP>  my current  application’s architecture was inspired by the article that you posted above. it is essentially MVP and uses Dependency injection etc. However it is still not modular enough and its features are not entirely decoupled. Our requirement is that we should be able to toggle out/in feature dependencies in the project. so we should at the end of the day be able to sell these features in our white labeled app as add ons. So a customer may get the app in its bare minimum spec or with many more feature dependencies. We would like to achieve something that is mentioned in this droid_con talk <https://droidcon.de/en/sessions/modular-android-development>
<@U3DCPPVCP> please share a link if you can
<https://labs.ribot.co.uk/android-application-architecture-8b6e34acda65#.lxnb95m3n>

attachments.title: Android Application Architecture
attachments.text: Our journey from standard Activities and AsyncTasks to a modern MVP-based architecture powered by RxJava.

text: However it is still not modular enough

text: I don't really get the need for it
^ I think it depends on your needs, at work we do one module per activity. you typically don’t want something around when you don’t need it
one module per activity also opens up the opportunity (or can force you) to use subcomponents, which is kinda tricky IMO
actually you can use it without it
Which I am
My activityComponent and ViewComponent are both SubComponents of the AppComponent
yeah, or that. but like i said it depends on your needs
could also depend on your architecture
MVP, etc
